Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Water quality impacts of hurricane Harvey: Distribution of metals and diversity of microbial communities in greater Houston

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal: 1759709
PI: Shankar Chellam

The category 4 hurricane named Harvey is the most extreme rain event in our country's history precipitating an estimated 12 trillion gallons of water over greater Houston alone. Humans, other animals, and the entire ecosystem have been exposed to myriad contaminants present in its floodwater and runoff. Hurricane samples will be characterized to identify different microbial communities to understand their role in the hydrological cycle. The hypothesis driving the work is that stormwater runoff mobilizes metals and microorganisms, which contribute to floodwater and runoff toxicity. Fifty representative elements, transition metals, and rare earth elements will be quantified. Microbial characterization will be used to determine any differences in microbial communities due to hurricane Harvey in an expansive urban environment. The primary objective is to present a comprehensive snapshot of metals concentrations and microorganism diversity with reference to microbial composition and prevalence in hurricane Harvey floodwaters in greater Houston. To this end, 36 samples have already been collected from 30 different locations representing a variety of urban and suburban land use patterns including residential, industrial, commercial, and educational activities.

Since hurricane Harvey is a 500-800 year storm, this represents a rare opportunity to characterize the elemental composition and dynamics of bacterial community diversity. Also, most previous floodwater and runoff measurements only considered a small subset of metals, whereas the PIs are targeting 50 main group elements, transition metals, and rare earths. Further, this is the first effort towards targeting high-throughput next generation sequencing to understand hurricane effects (if any) on the diversity of microbial community structures. Next Generation Sequencing can be performed long after sampling unlike traditional microbiological methods to precisely characterize various pathogens or their strains. Through integrated efforts between a microbiologist and an environmental engineer, a unique dataset will be created. The data will provide information on contaminant loading into the ecologically sensitive and economically important Galveston Bay. Knowledge of microbiological and chemical composition of floodwater and runoff provides insights into its toxicity. This information can also potentially improve strategies to manage stormwater in large watersheds. The doctoral student will obtain a unique perspective and gain valuable interdisciplinary experience working with a leading microbiologist. The results will be shared with news outlets including the Houston Chronicle and Public Broadcasting Stations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most extreme rain event in the United States' history, Hurricane Harvey stalled over greater Houston dropping 36-48 inches of rain causing catastrophic inundation and economic damages in the range $90 - $125 billion.  We hypothesized that Houstonians would have been exposed to potentially pathogenic microorganisms and toxic metals during the unprecedented flooding in its aftermath. 

Several graduate and undergraduate students under the tutelage of Prof. Shankar Chellam collaborated with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to develop a comprehensive snapshot of the metal distribution and microbial diversity in Hurricane Harvey floodwater remnants.  Grab samples were collected from different locations in greater Houston immediately following the dissipation the hurricane in early September 2017.  Separately twelve ?background? samples were collected in March 2018 for comparison.  We measured a wide range of representative elements, transition metals, and rare earth metals and analyzed microbial diversity using targeted and whole genome sequencing.  Three categories of elements were inferred by statistical analysis that was confirmed by chemical interrelationships.  Crustal elements that were simply mobilized by flood waters from the soil without significant anthropogenic influences included all rare earths along with Si, Ca, and Mg.  The second group (Sc, Cd, Mo, Sr, Sb, Ge, Sc, Ba, As, Se, Ga, and Zr) was consistent with vehicular contamination.  The third group (Al, Mn, Fe, Ni, K, Cs, Rb, Cr, Co, Sn, Zn, Cu, Pb, Ti, and W) was generically termed "anthropogenic activities/materials" because many of the metals herein originate from several different man made items and human activities in different land uses.   

Scientists at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention developed an efficient nucleic acid extraction protocol in conjunction with metagenomic sequencing to analyze microbial communities and assess the associated public health risks to Texas residents in Hurricane Harvey floodwater remnants.  NextGen sequencing offered a great opportunity for significantly advancing the scientific community's capabilities for analyzing environmental samples to 1) characterize exposure risks, 2) identify and understand disease transmission pathways, and 3) investigate best practices for managing, operating and treating water and waste systems to prevent and control disease transmission (e.g. from floodwaters).  Our metagenomic data successfully identified gene markers for indicator bacteria and waterborne pathogens associated with floodwater possibly contaminated with sewage or human fecal contamination.  We identified a diverse group of microorganisms, including fecal indicators, biofilm-associated microbes, opportunistic pathogens, viruses, bacteria and parasites related to different types of environmental samples.  With our novel approach, we could confirm the presence of Leptospira at a genus level. Additionally, we could identify human pathogenic species of Leptospira including L. santarosai, L. mayottensis, and L. interrogans along with an intermediate species, L. wolffii.  The dual indexed barcoding with pooled samples described provides cost-saving for large scale multiplexing.  The value of the shotgun metagenomic approach was successfully demonstrated by simultaneous detection of both opportunistic waterborne bacterial pathogens (Legionella, Mycobacterium, and Pseudomonas) and protozoan host Acanthamoeba. These groups of microorganisms typically co-exist in biofilms associated with drinking water distribution systems or premise plumbing demonstrating anthropogenic contamination of floodwater.  A metagenomic analysis of water samples also provided information on the presence of Vibrio and Leptospira.  In addition, fecal indicator bacteria, including Escherichia coli and Enterococcus faecalis were detected.  Several bacteriophages including those associated with Mycobacterium and Pseudomonas were also identified along with their bacterial hosts.  The knowledge we developed can help plan future investigations of microbial quality of floodwater to reduce exposure and potential infections from flood-damaged areas.

Additionally, a lesson plan was prepared focusing on density-driven mixing (i.e. cold and hot fluids) that result in severe weather such as hurricanes and communicated to fourth graders at Southwood Valley Elementary School.
